Name: Accessibility Grants SEO Wins
Excerpt: Accessibility makes a site’s content easily readable and beneficial to users of all ability levels. It also makes your site search engine optimized.

Name: Accessible Products are Easier for Everyone
Excerpt: Accessibility guidelines help everyone, not just for whom the guidelines are originally designed to help.

Name: ADA Accessibility Checklist
Excerpt: This checklist is a great first start for checking your site’s accessibility.

Name: ARIA Landmarks for Page
Excerpt: ARIA Landmarks help assistive technology to create a map of a page’s sections. This makes it easier for screen readers to navigate on a page.

Name: Attention Affects perceived Color Saturation
Excerpt: The attention to a color affects the user’s perception of a color’s saturation.

Name: Color & Conversion Rates
Excerpt: A couple of color guidelines: contrast is key and bright is memorable. It’s best to consider site goals when choosing colors.

Name: Color Influences Conversion Rates and Usability
Excerpt: Color can influence conversion rates. Choosing color must done considering usability and brand, not just aesthetics.

Name: Creativity is Aided by “Incubation” Periods
Excerpt: Creativity is helped by a period of time when one doesn’t focus on the problem, but rather allows the mind to wander off.

Name: Items Apparently Closer to the User’s Viewing Plane Need Less Visual Working Memory
Excerpt: Depth cues can help the user’s visual working memory prioritize which items to retain.

Name: Design for Dyslexia Friendly Readability
Excerpt: The British Dyslexia Association presents an easy-to-read selection of strategies for creating designs which are easier for dyslexic readers to consume.

Name: Differentiated Characters are More Legible
Excerpt: Complete with a list of sources, Typography Guru presents a compelling case for using typefaces with character differentiation.

Name: Don’t Remove Form Labels
Excerpt: Labels are crucial for assistive technology, so don’t remove them for visual purposes.

Name: Favorable expectations boost subjective ratings.
Excerpt: Users who read favorable reviews of a product before trying it gave it better reviews, even when the product didn’t always properly work.

Name: Google Tested 42 Versions of Blue Link Colors
Excerpt: Google tested 42 variations of the color blue used in search results to find the blue which resulted in the most clicks.

Name: Hiding and Showing Content
Excerpt: Certain ways of hiding and showing content may lack accessibility functionality. These methods will help that problem.

Name: How Our Eyes Move
Excerpt: Your eyes move in short, terse, back and forth motions, called saccades. Your eyes need 200ms to respond to a target.

Name: Hue and Saturation can provide reliable attention cues.
Excerpt: Lightness isn’t as reliable as hue and saturation for designing attention-directing elements.

Name: Make a Site Google-friendly
Excerpt: Google offers simple guidance for making a site easy for Google to index. This means your site will be easier to find.

Name: Making Link Colors WCAG 2.0 Compliant
Excerpt: This guide to link colors will make sure that link colors are in compliance with WCAG guidance. Better too much contrast than not enough.

Name: Microscopic Eye Movements and 20/20 Vision
Excerpt: 20/20 vision depends on the ability for your eyes’ muscles to move in microscopic increments.

Name: Minimize Memory Load
Source: UT Health School of Biomedical Informatics
Excerpt: Reducing users’ memory loads will help them create better data for your system.

Name: Minimum Color Contrast Guidelines
Excerpt: The W3C offers exhaustive guidance on minimum color contrast for user interface elements.

Name: Navigation Intent and Physical Motion Influence How Neurons Fire
Excerpt: Mice respond more strongly to recognizable landmarks when they are used for navigation rather than just recognition of location.

Name: People with Disabilities per Census
Excerpt: 2012 US Government Census reports 1 in 5 people identify as having a disability.

Name: Perceived Change is Proportional to Initial Stimuli
Excerpt: Wikipedia

Name: Priming the User to Take Action
Excerpt: Priming is a method of exposing a user to content or affordance so that they take action upon similar content or affordance later.

Name: Reading on Smartphones Reduces Comprehension
Excerpt: Reading on smartphones is harder than on paper. Comprehension is reduced and breathing is also affected.

Name: Tab Navigation with Tabindex and Focus
Excerpt: Keyboard navigation is important for users and it’s affected by DOM order and visual signals of tab location on a page.

Name: The Brain Needs 13 Milliseconds to Process Images
Excerpt: Your brain can process an image in just 13 milliseconds. How can we use this a better user experience?

Name: TV Viewing & Cognitive Decline
Excerpt: Excessive, passive, television viewing in older adults can lead to cognitive decline. Active viewing does not show the same results.

Name: Typeface and Font Usage Guidelines
Excerpt: Style and aesthetics shouldn’t be the first considerations when choosing a website typeface. WebAIM presents guidelines and reasons for why other factors should come first.

Name: United Nation and Accessibility
Excerpt: The UN has released a statement exhibiting their commitment for the right of disabled persons.

Name: Users prefer familiar and simpler designs.
Excerpt: Google’s own research shows that users favor designs that are simple and familiar. Complex or unfamiliar designs are ignored more quickly.

Name: Visual Working Memory
Excerpt: We recognize associations between objects using cues such as color, proximity, similarity, and connectedness, among other factors. Some of these cues are stronger than others and some can be combined for better results.

Name: Visual Working Memory is enhanced by Objects’ Familiarity
Excerpt: Visual working memory is influenced by the type of information to be remembered. Familiar objects in working memory carry greater capacity to increase the working memory’s load.

Name: Warm background colors are better for reading experience.
Source: Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science
Excerpt: Researchers have found that warmer background colors provide a better reading experience for both dyslexic and non dyslexic readers.

Name: Writing Notes is Better than Typing Them
Excerpt: When you’re reading or studying, it’s better to write out your notes by hand. You remember the material better because more parts of your brain are active than if you’re just typing.
